awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Wide-Field Infrared Camera for Robotic Surveys of the Dynamic Astronomical Sky
awd_abstract_narration:
The US astronomical community has embarked on a systematic effort to monitor the dynamic sky, leveraging advances in robotic telescope operation, remote-imaging sensors, large-scale computing and machine learning to find, classify, and unveil transient cosmic sources. Numerous surveys already operate at visible wavelengths, but the high cost of conventional sensors has discouraged similar efforts in the infrared (IR), despite strong scientific motivation.  Advances in material growth driven by the defense and surveillance markets have yielded lower-cost IR sensors of the semiconductor InGaAs, with sufficiently low noise to detect faint astronomical sources. The Wide-field Infrared Transient Explorer (WINTER) will mosaic six High Definition format InGaAs detectors to produce the world's widest-area IR camera and conduct a deep robotic survey of the dynamic infrared sky. In addition to its primary science mission, studying how the heaviest elements of the periodic table are synthesized in colliding neutron stars identified via gravitational waves, WINTER will devote observing time to support undergraduate research and laboratory education at the intersection of Big Data and the physical sciences.

WINTER is an infrared camera with a 1.2 x 1.0 degree field of view that will be installed on a dedicated 1-meter robotic telescope at Palomar Observatory. A simple prototype shows that thermo-electrically cooled InGaAs behind an ambient temperature optical train yields broadband images (at 0.9-1.7 microns) limited by shot noise from the sky, rather than sensor noise. This removes the requirement for cryogenic optics and vacuum cryostats, greatly reducing system cost and complexity relative to traditional IR imagers with HgCdTe sensors. During each year of a 5-year baseline survey, WINTER will monitor the entire Northern sky to a depth of J=19.2 (single visit), or J=20 (combined), and release calibrated images and transient alerts to the public. WINTER is sensitive to emission from the r-process enhanced ejecta of kilonovae over the full horizon of Advanced LIGO, and will autonomously interrupt its sky survey to search for the isotropic infrared counterparts of gravitational-wave events.  WINTER's IR capability is uniquely sensitive to emission from both binary neutron star mergers and neutron star-black hole mergers independent of viewing angle, opacity, mass ratio and remnant lifetime.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have designed, built, and deployed a new ground-based fully-autonomous infrared survey instrument for time-domain astronomy, the Wide-field INfrared Transient ExploreR (WINTER), developed primarily through funding from this NSF Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award in 2018.  The WINTER camera was commissioned in June 2023 on a dedicated 1-m robotic telescope at Palomar Observatory. WINTER observes in the Y, J, and a custom shortened H-band, spanning 900-1700 nm in the shortwave infrared. The custom camera features six indium gallium arsenide (InGaAs) detectors coupled to the telescope with a novel image slicer design, achieving a >1deg square field of view. As of February 2024, WINTER has completed commissioning and begun regular operations performing a seeing-limited time domain survey of the infrared (IR) sky to detect, discover, and characterize astrophysical time-domain phenomena. WINTER achieves a J-band limiting magnitude (AB) of 19 in 960 s, its baseline survey mode. This represents a dramatic improvement in depth over previous infrared surveys like 2MASS, though our team continues to investigate future upgrades to improve this depth. As a dedicated observatory for real-time detection and rapid follow-up of infrared transient and variable targets, WINTER represents a new capability for multi-messenger astrophysics with a unique discovery space for astrophysical transients.

The WINTER MRI award supported the design, construction, and commissioning of the infrared camera at the heart of this new observatory. MIT designed, assembled, aligned and installed the WINTER infrared camera. Design and production of the InGaAs sensors at Teledyne-FLIR  and the readout electronics, firmware, and software at MIT were significant research and development efforts, requiring close collaboration between the WINTER team and the sensor vendor. The WINTER sensors are the largest commercially-produced InGaAs detectors. A key requirement of the camera design was to achieve a nearly continuous 1 deg sq. field of view despite splitting the field between 6 individually packaged sensors that cannot be directly abutted. Achieving this required developing a novel compact imaging design, where each sensor has its own identical optics which are truncated and close-packed together achieving a >95% fill factor over the field of view.  Through close communication with the lens manufacturer (Optimax) we developed a method to produce lens arrays ground and assembled to micron level tolerances that could be practically aligned in the lab using available metrology.

In addition to the camera itself, our collaboration developed the complete observatory from the ground up during the period of support from the MRI. Using additional funds from Caltech and MIT, Caltech Optical Observatories overhauled an existing dome at Palomar Observatory for WINTER. The dome control hardware and software was completely redone, and extensive new support infrastructure was built at the site. A commercial 1-m robotic telescope was installed and commissioned in June 2021.

Our collaboration developed robust custom robotic software routines which allow the WINTER observatory to collect and analyze data completely autonomously without the need for operator intervention. A WINTER Supervisor Program written at MIT (WSP) which handles autonomous scheduling of both surveys and target-of-opportunity (TOO) interrupts, as well as control and remote monitoring of the observatory, telescope, and cameras. WSP is implemented with a custom software suite based on a series of multithreaded python daemons, operating on a distributed computer network. Caltech developed an automated data reduction pipeline for WINTER, the Modular Image Reduction and Analysis Resource (MIRAR). MIRAR handles astrometric and photometric calibration of the images, produces composite stacks of dithered images, and executes automated reference image subtraction routines to detect transient and variable astronomical images. As WINTER builds up its own volume of reference survey data, the pipeline primarily uses reference images from the UKIRT infrared survey. Candidate sources are passed to the Fritz time domain alert marshal, an API-driven web portal for tracking, classifying, distributing alerts for astrophysical transients, and for dispatching follow-up observations with WINTER and other collaboration resources. 

WINTER has been and continues to be a valuable training opportunity for young scientists and engineers. WINTER supported two grad students through their PhD, and provided projects for 5 undergrad students at MIT and 2 at Caltech along with 4 high school students. Many of these undergraduate students returned for multiple semester and summer sessions allowing them to dig deep into astronomical data analysis, software/controls, mechanical and thermal engineering projects. Working with the PI and a graduate student, two undergraduate students developed a telescope design module for a local high school. This module was postponed due to COVID lockdowns, and renovations to our collaborating high school maker space, but is now being reopened. Efforts to use WINTER as a training facility are continuing. As the instrument transitions into regular survey operations, we will work with MIT undergraduate physics instructors to integrate WINTER-based observing into the existing observational astronomy courses.
